# chronic disease -- it was felt that the patient 's deficiency of oxygen could have been caused by his chronic disease that has significantly worsened or is the substrate upon which another process is acting .

patient is a 85 year old male with severe heart disease after heart bypass surgeryx2 , prosthesis consisting of tissue and part mitral valve replacement , dilated cardiomyopathy with blood pumping score 25 % who presents with worsening shortness of breath . 
on 9-28 the patient again began to complain of abdominal pain , diffuse in nature , constant and sharp in nature , rated 9-8 . 
she was noted to have abnormal thickening and edema of the triangular folds of mucous membrane , right greater than left , as well as nonspecific circumferential edema at the pharynx and the esophagus junction on a imaging scan of her neck at the outside hospital . 
the pain itself is not associated with sick , vomiting or sweating . 
he beleves that he had a 'cold ' approximately one week ago , with cough , runny nose and subjective fevers . 
the patient had a single episode of chest pain while in the hospital which was relieved by sublingual nitroglycerin . 
patient should have a repeat head imaging in a few months after discharge . 
upon further investigation , his pain was noted to be reproducible by physical exam , namely by pressing down on his head and turning his neck to the left . 
the patient was monitored on telemetry with no abnormal position noted . 
he was transferred to coronary care unit for further observation on aggrenox drops and nitroglycerin drops to prevent narrowing of the arteries . 
per infectious dose , given clinical improvement will continue with current regimen . 
initial labs were notable for a normal white blood cell ( 7.0 ) , proportion of red blood cells ( 40.9 ) , and levels of a protein of 1180 .

at this point she called her life and she was brought to hospital1 18 .
